div.head: OSWALD JONAS CORRESPONDENCE
div.p: The 20-year-long exchanges between Oswald Jonas and Schenker ‒ spanning 1918 to 1938 ‒ constitute one of the most important narratives among the Schenker correspondences. Jonas was Schenker's pupil 1918‒20, and thereafter studied with Hans Weisse. His value to Schenker increased during the 1930s with the emergence of his book Das Wesen des musikalischen Kunstwerks (1934).

The newly available material, covering 1932 to 1938, is dominated by the preparation and publication of that book in parallel with Schenker's completion of Der freie Satz, and by the unpredictabilities of Anthony van Hoboken as the financial backer of both works (something which arouses Schenker’s indignation).

With the coming to power of the Nazis, Jonas's work in Berlin rapidly diminishes from early 1933. One by one doors close on him as a Jew. His situation becomes increasingly difficult, but his comments to Schenker are always so guarded that one has to read between the lines.
In two striking letters ‒ OJ 5/18, 33 and 49 (December 21, 1933 and August 2, 1934) ‒ Schenker makes far-reaching statements about his own Jewishness.

Jonas's communications with Jeanette Schenker after Heinrich's death allude to her giving him privileged access to Heinrich's unpublished papers, and to his plans with Salzer to found the periodical Der Dreiklang.

div.head: OTTO ERICH DEUTSCH CORRESPONDENCE
div.p: The correspondence of the musicologist and bibliographer Otto Erich Deutsch and his wife Hannah to Schenker and his wife Jeanette spans twenty-six years, from 1913 to 1939. The subjects addressed in their exchanges vary widely and were substantive. Deutsch was one of the relatively few professional people whom Schenker generally held in high regard.

The correspondence between Deutsch and Schenker in 1922 is primarily concerned with Schenker’s fee for his facsimile edition of Beethoven’s “Moonlight” Sonata (Vienna: UE, 1921), which was part of the series “Musical Rarities: Viennese Connoisseur Prints,” of which Deutsch was general editor, and the hunt for other suitable facsimile-edition subjects. Correspondence for 1923 is lost, but that surviving from 1924 again revolves around financial matters. 1925 sees discussion of Schenker’s contribution to a Schubert special issue of Moderne Welt (December 1, 1925), which Deutsch edited, and during 1925‒26 there is an increasing number of references to social gatherings.

div.head: SCHENKER’S DIARIES JANUARY 1931 TO MAY 1934
div.p: These years show, above all, a marked decline in Schenker’s health – he found it necessary to consult a doctor frequently – and he tried reducing his workload in order to concentrate as much as possible on Free Composition, the writing and proofreading of which is sometimes recorded in meticulous detail. He had laid The Art of Performance aside in December 1930, but was still kept busy revising his edition of the Beethoven sonatas, preparing the text for Brahms’s manuscript study of consecutive fifths and octaves, working with students and engravers on the Five Analyses in Sketchform, and writing short polemical essays for Hermann Rinn’s Der Kunstwart (later renamed the Deutsche Zeitschrift).

We also witness the fluctuating relationship with his pupil and principal benefactor, Anthony van Hoboken; his continued collaboration with Otto Erich Deutsch; and the moments of elation bestowed upon him by the activity of a younger generation, including Hans Weisse, Oswald Jonas, and Israel Citkowitz. Perhaps unsurprisingly, one observes an increase in expressions of spirituality, as Schenker faces each new year "mit Gott", reads from the Old Testament while on holiday, and conceives Free Composition as a religious offering.
